content.text: How to Reverse a String in Python
Learn how to reverse a String in Python.
content.html: Learn how to reverse a String in Python.

content.text: There is no built-in function to reverse a String in Python.
content.html: There is no built-in function to reverse a String in Python.

content.text: The fastest (and easiest?) way is to use a slice that steps backwards, -1 .
content.html: The fastest (and easiest?) way is to use a slice that steps backwards, -1.

content.code_html:
txt = "Hello World"[::-1]
print(txt)

content.text: We have a string, "Hello World", which we want to reverse:
content.html: We have a string, "Hello World", which we want to reverse:

content.code_html:
txt = "Hello World" [::-1]
print(txt)

content.text: Create a slice that starts at the end of the string, and moves backwards.
content.html: Create a slice that starts at the end of the string, and moves backwards.

content.text: In this particular example, the slice statement [::-1] means start at the end of the string and end at position 0, move with the step -1 , negative one, which means one step backwards.
content.html: In this particular example, the slice statement [::-1] means start at the end of the string and end at position 0, move with the step -1, negative one, which means one step backwards.

content.code_html:
txt = "Hello World" [::-1]
print(txt)

content.text: Now we have a string txt that reads "Hello World" backwards.
content.html: Now we have a string txt that reads "Hello World" backwards.

content.text: Print the String to demonstrate the result
content.html: Print the String to demonstrate the result

content.code_html:
txt = "Hello World"[::-1]
print(txt)

content.text: If you like to have a function where you can send your strings, and return them backwards, you can create a function and insert the code from the example above.
content.html: If you like to have a function where you can send your strings, and return them backwards, you can create a function and insert the code from the example above.

syntaxHighlighting.text: "I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

syntax_highlighting.text: "I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

content.code_html:
def my_function(x):
  return x[::-1]

mytxt = my_function("I wonder how this text looks like backwards")

print(mytxt)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

content.text: Create a function that takes a String as an argument.
content.html: Create a function that takes a String as an argument.

syntaxHighlighting.text: "I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

syntax_highlighting.text: "I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

content.code_html:

  return x[::-1]

mytxt = my_function("I wonder how this text looks like backwards")

print(mytxt)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

content.text: Slice the string starting at the end of the string and move backwards.
content.html: Slice the string starting at the end of the string and move backwards.

syntaxHighlighting.text:

  my_function("I wonder how this text looks like backwards")
  print(mytxt)
"I wonder how this text looks like backwards"

 print(mytxt)
"I wonder how this text looks like backwards"
